In addition to participating in periodic mutual aid meetings, SPPR conducts periodic emergency drills that involve emergency response organizations, and the refinery provides periodic refresher training to local emergency responders regarding the hazards of regulated substances in the refinery.

1.8 Planned Changes to Improve Safety

SPPR constantly strives to improve the safety of its operations through periodic safety reviews, the incident investigation program, and a program soliciting safety suggestions from the workers. SPPR resolves all findings from PHAs, some of which result in modifications to the process.

of the RMP rule which includes on-site impact and off-site impact. Based on this review, no incidents were determined to be reportable under the provisions of the RMP regulation.

1.7 Emergency Response Program

SPPR maintains a written emergency response program which is in place to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment. The program consists of procedures for responding to a release of a regulated substance, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released. The procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures, refinery evacuation plans and accounting for refinery personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs, and post-incident cleanup and decontamination requirements. In addition, SPPR has procedures that address maintenance, inspection, and testing of emergency response equipment, as well as instructions that address the use of emergency response equipment. Employees receive training in these procedures to perform their specific emergency response duties. The Emergency Response Team conducts additional training sessions so that they can safely handle potential emergency situations. The emergency response program is updated when necessary, based on modifications made to refinery processes or facilities.

The overall emergency response program for SPPR is coordinated with the facility's Emergency Response Team (ERT), WAKOTA CAER, a local emergency response cooperative, and with offsite response agencies that would be requested to support emergency response efforts as needed. This coordination includes periodic meetings which include local emergency response officials, local government officials, and industry representatives. SPPR has around-the-clock communications
capability with appropriate government officials and emergency response organizations (e

reports can be reviewed during future PHAs and PHA revalidations.

Compliance Audits

To help ensure that the accident prevention program is functioning properly, SPPR periodically conducts audits to determine whether the procedures and practices required by the accident prevention program are being implemented. Compliance audits are conducted at least every 3 years. The audit team develops findings that are forwarded to SPPR management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team's findings are tracked until they are complete. The final resolution of each finding is documented, and the two most recent audit reports are retained.

1.5 Chemical-specific Prevention Steps

The processes at SPPR have hazards that must be managed to ensure continued safe operation. The accident prevention program summarized previously is applied to all USEPA RMP-covered processes at SPPR. Collectively, these prevention program activities help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures or human errors.

The refinery has installed Safety Instrumented Systems (SIS) on all process heaters and boilers to reduce fire, explosion, toxic gas releases or spills through adoption of design standards that represent industry best practices. These systems provide interlock systems which monitor critical operating conditions (fuel pressure, temperature, flow, etc.) during heater startup and during normal operations. Deviations from normal ranges for these conditions will prevent startup or will initiate a controlled shutdown.

In addition to the accident prevention program activities, SPPR has safety features on many units to help (1) contain/control a release, (2) quickly detect a release, and (3) reduce the consequences of a release. The following types of safety features are used in various processes:

Release Detection

- Hydrocarbon detectors with alarms in the liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) storage and other areas;
- Hy

park-producing activities (hot work), entry into a confined space, and excavation where underground utilities may be present. These procedures and safe work permit system, along with training of affected personnel, form a system to enable operations and maintenance activities to be performed safely.

Management of Change

SPPR has a comprehensive system to manage changes to processes. This system requires that changes to items such as process equipment, chemicals, technology (including process operating conditions), procedures, and other facility changes be properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented. Changes are reviewed to (1) ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards and (2) verify that existing controls have not been compromised by the
change. Affected chemical hazard information, process operating limits, and equipment information, as well as procedures, are updated to incorporate these changes. In addition, operating and maintenance personnel are provided with any necessary training on the change.

Incident Investigation

SPPR promptly investigates all incidents that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in, a fire/explosion, toxic gas release, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury. The goal of each investigation is to determine the facts and develop corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident. The investigation team documents its findings, develops recommendations to prevent a recurrence, and forwards these results to SPPR management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the investigation team's findings and recommendations are tracked until they are complete. The final resolution of each finding or recommendation is documented, and the investigation results are reviewed with employees (including contractors) who could be affected by the findings. Incident investigation reports are retained for at least 5 years so that the

clude: (1) conducting training, (2) developing written procedures, (3) performing periodic inspections and tests, (4) correcting identified deficiencies, and (5) applying quality assurance measures. In combination, these activities form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process equipment.

Maintenance personnel receive training on (1) an overview of the process, (2) safety and health hazards, (3) applicable maintenance procedures, (4) emergency response plans, and (5) applicable safe work practices to help ensure that they can perform their job in a safe manner. Written procedures help ensure that work is performed in a consistent manner and provide a basis for training. Inspections and tests are performed to help ensure that equipment functions as intended, and to verify that equipment is within acceptable limits (e.g., adequate wall thickness for pressure vessels). If a deficiency is identified, employees will correct the deficiency before placing the equipment back into service (if possible), or a management of change team will review the use of the equipment and determine what actions are necessary to ensure the safe operation of the equipment.

Another integral part of the mechanical integrity program is quality assurance. SPPR incorporates quality assurance measures into equipment purchases and repairs to verify that new equipment is suitable for its intended use and that proper materials and spare parts are used when repairs are made.

Safe Work Practices

SPPR has safe work practice procedures and a safe work permit system in place to help ensure worker and process safety. Examples of items include included in the procedures and safe work permit system include: control of the entry/presence/exit of support personnel, a lockout/tagout procedure to ensure isolation of energy sources for equipment undergoing maintenance, safe removal of hazardous materials before process piping or equipment is opened, control of welding and other s

dge and skills, (3) are aware of the hazards in their workplace, (4) understand what they should do in the event of an emergency, (5) understand and follow site safety rules, and (6) inform SPPR personnel of any hazards that they find during their work. This is accomplished by providing contractors with access to (1) a process overview, (2) information about safety and health hazards, (3) emergency response plan requirements, (4) safe work practices, and (5) work permit processes (i.e., for hot work, confined space, etc.) prior to their beginning work. In addition, SPPR evaluates contractor safety programs and performance during the selection of a contractor and conducts annual audits of each contractor's safety program to ensure that the relevant requirements are being met. Additionally, SPPR personnel periodically monitor or audit contractor performance to ensure that contractors are fulfilling their safety obligations.

Pre-startup Safety Reviews

SPPR conducts a pre-startup safety review for any new equipment or equipment modification that require a change in the process safety information. The purpose of the review is to ensure that safety features, procedures, personnel, and the equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment into service. This review provides one additional means to verify that construction is in accordance with the design specifications and that supporting systems are operationally ready. The review team uses checklists to verify all readiness. A review involves field verification of the construction and serves a quality assurance function by requiring verification that accident prevention program requirements are properly implemented.

Mechanical Integrity

SPPR has practices and procedures to inspect and maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pumps and compressors, and emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition. The basic aspects of this program in

reviewed annually certified as current and accurate. Procedures are maintained current by revising them as necessary to reflect changes made to the process. Operating employees review and approve operating procedures as part of the annual certification. In addition, SPPR operating procedures provide guidance on how to respond to events that result in exceeding safe operating limits for specific process or equipment parameters. The written operating procedures are readily available to operators in the process units and for other personnel to use as necessary to safely perform their job tasks.

Training

To complement the written procedures for process operations, SPPR has implemented a company training program for all employees involved in operating a process. New employees must receive basic training in SPPR operations. After successfully completing this training, a new operator is paired with a senior operator to learn process-specific duties and tasks. After operators demonstrate (e.g., through tests, skills demonstration) having adequate knowledge to perform the duties and tasks in a safe manner on their own, they can work independently. In addition, all operating employees periodically receive refresher training to ensure that their skills and knowledge are maintained at an
acceptable level. This refresher training is conducted at least every 3 years. All of this training is documented for each operator, including the means used to verify that the operator understood the training. Additional training for operators and other refinery personnel includes fire training and computer-based training related to safety and environmental programs.

Contractors

SPPR uses contractors to supplement its work force during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities. Because some contractors work on or near process equipment, SPPR has procedures in place to ensure that contractors (1) perform their work in a safe manner, (2) have the appropriate knowle

nking, and hazard mitigation. Within the PHA program, each process is thoroughly and systematically examined by qualified team members to identify specific conditions which could result in accidental releases and to ensure that adequate measures are implemented to manage those hazards.

SPPR primarily uses the hazard and operability (HAZOP) analysis technique to perform these evaluations. HAZOP analysis is recognized as one of the most systematic and thorough hazard evaluation techniques available. The analyses are conducted using a team of people who have operating experience and maintenance experience as well as engineering expertise. This team identifies and evaluates hazards of the process as well as accident prevention and mitigation measures, and makes recommendations for additional prevention and/or mitigation measures when the team believes such measures are necessary.

The PHA team recommendations are forwarded to local management for resolution. Approved safety improvements being implemented in response to PHA team recommendations are tracked until they are complete. The final resolution of each recommendation is documented and retained.

SPPR periodically updates and revalidates the PHA results. These periodic reviews are conducted at least every 5 years and will be conducted at this frequency until the process is no longer operating. The PHA Team considers off-site effects of potential releases in all PHAs. The results and recommendations from these updates are documented and retained.

Operating Procedures

SPPR maintains written procedures that address various modes of process operations, such as (1) unit startup, (2) normal operations, (3) temporary operations, (4) emergency shutdown, (5) normal shutdown, and (6) initial startup of a new process. These procedures can be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators. Procedures, except temporary and initial startup, are periodically

arameters and specific chemical inventories, and equipment design basis/configuration information. Specific departments within SPPR are assigned responsibility for maintaining up-to-date process safety information. This information is readily accessible by all SPPR personnel.

Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in Safety Data Sheets (SDSs). This information is supplemented by documents that specifically address known corrosion concerns and any known compatibility issues associated with the inadvertent mixing of chemicals. For specific process areas, SPPR has documented safety-related upper and lower operating limits for specific process parameters (e.g., temperature, level, composition) in Critical Process Variable Documents. SPPR operates equipment within these limits by using process controls and monitoring instruments, highly trained personnel, and protective instrument systems (e.g., automated shutdown systems). SPPR also maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment. This information includes materials of construction, design pressure and temperature ratings, electrical rating of equipment, relief system design, applicable codes and standards, safety systems, etc. This information, in combination with written procedures and trained personnel, provides a basis for establishing inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes to ensure that safety features in the process are not compromised.

SPPR also maintains Troubleshooting Guides for all process units which identify the consequences from operating outside the normal operating range and provides steps for reestablishing operation within the normal operating range.

Process Hazard Analysis

SPPR has a comprehensive Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) program for hazard identification, risk ra

the additional information submitted to USEPA with this executive summary, and that information has been shared with the emergency response organizations and with members of the local community. If you are interested in this information, please contact the SPPR PSM/RMP Coordinator at 651-459-9771.

1.4 Accidental Release Prevention Program

The following is a summary of the general accident prevention programs in place at SPPR. Because the processes regulated by the USEPA RMP regulation are also subject to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) process safety management (PSM) standard and because the OSHA PSM requirements are very similar to the USEPA RMP requirements, this summary also addresses each of the OSHA PSM elements. The PSM program at this facility has been extended by SPPR, where necessary, to satisfy USEPA's Program Level 3 accident prevention program requirements.

Employee Participation

SPPR encourages employees to participate in all facets of process safety management and accident prevention. Examples of employee participation range from updating and compiling technical documents to participating as a member on the process hazard analysis (PHA), incident investigation, and compliance audit teams. Employees have access to all information created as part of the SPPR accident prevention program. Specific ways that employees can be involved in the accident prevention program are documented in an employee participation plan that is maintained at SPPR and addresses each accident prevention program element. In addition, SPPR has a number of initiatives that address process safety and employee safety issues, such as a Behavior-Based Safety Program and monthly employee safety communication meetings.

Process Safety Information

SPPR maintains a variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the processes. These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, limits for key process p

use of their flammable process materials. These units are listed in the RMP data included with this summary.

SPPR also handles two toxic substances regulated by the RMP rule in sufficient quantity to be covered by the RMP rule. Hydrofluoric acid (HF) is used as a catalyst in the HF Alkylation unit to make high quality gasoline blending components, and hydrogen sulfide (H2S) is present as a byproduct of the desulfurization (sulfur removal) process in the refinery Heavy Distillate Hydrotreating (HDH) unit.

1.3 Offsite Consequence Analysis

SPPR performed an offsite consequence analysis to estimate the potential for an accidental release of a regulated substance that could affect the public or the environment. The offsite consequence analysis consists of evaluating both worst case scenarios and alternative release scenarios for flammables and toxics as defined by the USEPA. A worst-case release scenario event is unlikely to ever occur. An alternative release scenario represents a release that might occur during the lifetime of a facility like SPPR. Alternative release scenarios can be used to help local emergency responders, such as fire and police departments and the county and state emergency managers, to improve local emergency response planning. Release scenario analyses have been submitted to USEPA and have shared that information with the organizations involved in emergency response activities. It should be noted that no events in the magnitude of these worst-case or alternative incident scenarios have ever occurred at the facility. In the case of some of these incident scenarios, emergency mitigation systems would reduce the consequences of the events should they occur. In all cases, should such events occur, the emergency response plan would be implemented, local authorities would be notified, and appropriate actions would be taken to protect both employees and the public.

As stated previously, details regarding these scenarios have been provided in

tes each situation and responds based on our internal capabilities and training and, if necessary, contacts the state and local agencies to assist in controlling and containing the release and to prevent and/or reduce the consequences of the release.

The SPPR General Refinery Manager has overall responsibility for the development and implementation of the risk management program for USEPA-regulated processes at the facility. However, the specific responsibilities for certain aspects of that program have been delegated by the General Refinery Manager to other personnel who report either directly, or indirectly through other management personnel, to the General Refinery Manager. Those relationships are depicted on the organization chart maintained by the General Refinery Manager's staff. Specific responsibility for the implementation of the Process Safety Management (PSM) and accident prevention program has been delegated to the PSM/RMP Coordinator. Similarly, responsibility for the RMP hazard assessment and risk management plan has been delegated to the PSM/RMP Coordinator. The emergency response program, including compliance with the RMP aspects of that effort, is the responsibility of the refinery's ERT/Fire Chief. In keeping with our policy that safe operation is part of every employee's job, many other personnel are also involved in RMP activities on an ongoing basis.

1.2 SPPR Regulated Substances

SPPR operates a petroleum refinery and petroleum products terminal facility located in St. Paul Park, Minnesota. Crude petroleum is the raw material used to make a variety of petroleum-based products, including gasoline, diesel fuel, kerosene, and liquefied petroleum gases such as propane and butane. Many of these products are flammable substances specifically listed by USEPA in the RMP rule and are present in our process units above the USEPA threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds. In total, we have 16 different process units that are covered by the RMP rule beca

Risk Management Program Plan Executive Summary
Marathon Petroleum Company, St. Paul Park Refinery (SPPR)
May 3, 2022

1. EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Marathon Petroleum Company, St. Paul Park Refinery (SPPR), is committed to operating in a manner that protects its employees and contractors, the public, and the environment. As part of this commitment, SPPR has established systems to help ensure safe operation of the processes at this facility. One part of these systems is a risk management program (RMP) that helps manage the risks at SPPR and that complies with the requirements of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's (USEPA) rule 40 CFR part 68, Accidental Release Prevention Requirements: Risk Management Programs (the RMP rule). One of the requirements of the RMP rule is to submit a Risk Management Plan (RMP) describing the risk management program at SPPR. This document is intended to satisfy the RMP executive summary requirements of the RMP rule and to provide the public with a description of the risk management program at SPPR.

1.1 Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

SPPR is committed to the safety of its workers and the public and to the protection of the environment through the prevention of accidental releases of hazardous substances. SPPR employs highly skilled and trained operating personnel and has implemented administrative and operational controls to reduce the likelihood of hazardous substance releases. In addition, a trained Emergency Response Team (ERT) equipped with dedicated equipment resources is available to respond to a significant accidental release. The overall emergency response program for SPPR is coordinated with the facility Emergency Response Team (ERT), an internal Emergency Operations Center team, WAKOTA CAER (a local emergency response cooperative), state and local government agencies, and off-site emergency response resources that could be called to provide support in the event of an incident.
